notes: Brass-era four-cylinder models (Models 10, 14, 16, 17, 19, etc.). Inline-4 engines. Open touring and roadster bodies predominant. RWD with chain or shaft drive. Brass radiators, acetylene/oil lamps, hand-crank starting, mechanical brakes on rear wheels only. Wooden-spoke wheels, wooden body framing. Difficulty modifier 1.4 reflects brass-era fragile construction, hand-fitted components, obsolete ignition/brake systems, wooden components, and near-zero parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Model history articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

Brass-era six-cylinder models (1914-1925). Inline-6 engines, smoother than contemporary four-cylinders. Multiple body styles including enclosed sedans in later years. RWD. Brass/nickel trim, wooden-spoke wheels initially, transitioning to disc wheels by early 1920s. Hand-crank starting, mechanical brakes. Difficulty modifier 1.35 reflects brass-era construction, transition to 'modern' era, hand-fitted components, and very limited parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Six history articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

D-Series brass-era touring cars (D-44, D-45, D-46, D-47 models, 1916-1917). Inline-6 engines. Open touring and roadster bodies. RWD. Brass radiator, acetylene lighting, hand-crank starting. Wooden-spoke wheels, leather upholstery. WWI-era production. Difficulty modifier 1.4 reflects WWI brass-era construction, extreme rarity, hand-fitted components, obsolete systems, and near-zero parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick D-Series articles, December 19, 2024 revision.
